discussion.content:
It's D 

https://www.crime-scene-investigator.net/tagging.html

questions.question_text: A computer at a company was used to commit a crime. The system was seized and removed for further analysis. Which of the following is the purpose of labeling cables and connections when seizing the computer system?

choices.C: To block any communication with the computer system from attack
choices.D: To document the model, manufacturer, and type of cables connected
choices.B: To maintain the chain of custody
choices.A: To capture the system configuration as it was at the time it was removed

discussion.content:
I think it is E, at least if we're talking about brute force login attempts against the domain controller. Placing administrators in a new security group would allow us to define better security settings (like account lockout after X incorrect login attempts, or timeouts, or whatever).
Could be wrong though.

comments.content: Yes, but accessing those hashes would already require access to the system, no? In which case the brute force login attempts were successful.

To*

Also bruteforcing is online cracking. Hash cracking of lanman hashes is done on offline cracking/BF, honestly it not related to each other, correct me if Im wrong. This is really frustrating.

discussion.content: I think this is A. Moving the admin accounts to a new security group offers very little value as we dont know details about the new security group. The new security group might even contain the same security settings as the current group. As with letter A, disabling the LM hashes as they are relatively prone to brute force attacks

choices.A: Disable the ability to store a LAN manager hash.
choices.E: Move administrator accounts to a new security group.

questions.question_text: A cybersecurity analyst is hired to review the security measures implemented within the domain controllers of a company. Upon review, the cybersecurity analyst notices a brute force attack can be launched against domain controllers that run on a Windows platform. The first remediation step implemented by the cybersecurity analyst is to make the account passwords more complex. Which of the following is the NEXT remediation step the cybersecurity analyst needs to implement?

choices.C: An externally hosted website should be prepared in advance to ensure that when an incident occurs victims have timely access to notifications from a non- compromised recourse.
choices.B: Guidance from laws and regulations should be considered when deciding who must be notified in order to avoid fines and judgements from non-compliance.
choices.D: The HR department should have information security personnel who are involved in the investigation of the incident sign non-disclosure agreements so the company cannot be held liable for customer data that might be viewed during an investigation.
choices.A: The first responder should contact law enforcement upon confirmation of a security incident in order for a forensics team to preserve chain of custody.

discussion.content: definitely B.
I'm thinking this should be B. A is incorrect because law enforcement should only be conducted when the security incident is related to a crime or something. C and D seems incorrect also.

I picked B because I always thought you'd keep it inside the company unless there was something like sicko child porn, etc. involved. Now I wonder what it is for sure. Sounds like the consensus is A or B but nobody came up with a definite answer.
Its def B

" if a data breach occurs, only affected parties should be notified to keep an incident from becoming a media headline"

I don't think informing law enforcement would be a good idea so B is the answer.

comments.content: But if it was a breach, then most likely law enforcement would need to be contacted.

discussion.content: Law enforcement should be contacted by management or some high level executive/security officer. First responder won’t be the one communicating with either the media or law. Answer should be B
the answer is B. the company officer made a suggestion and the security guy was asked to respond to the company officer. so B is the right reply to the suggestion made.
The answer is A

comments.content: Okay wait a minute.. maybe I'm wrong after all. Ready this: https://shawnetuma.com/cyber-law-resources/guide-reporting-cybersecurity-incidents-law-enforcement-governmental-regulatory-agencies/#_Toc465982694

discussion.content:
This should be - with 99.9% certainty - B. Refer to https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-61r2.pdf section 2.3.4.2 Law Enforcement:

"Law enforcement should be contacted through designated individuals in a manner consistent with the requirements of the law and the organization’s procedures. Many organizations prefer to appoint one incident response team member as the primary POC with law enforcement. This person should be familiar with the reporting procedures for all relevant law enforcement agencies and well prepared to recommend which agency, if any, should be contacted."
Agreed that this is definitely B.
This question was in the exam :)
B is definitely correct. compliance is key in such situations. If first responder contacts law enforcement, they have acted alone, and law enforcement will hint the media.

comments.content: A security incident could mean many different things. Not necessarily a crime. PCI or HIPPA data would dictate how the incident responder would act
Agree the topic is breach, so you've already lost control hence law enforcement needs to be involved

discussion.content: The questions says its a Data Breach,so law enforcement has to be involved in such cases ,So my answer is A.Correct If I am wrong

questions.question_text: A security analyst is adding input to the incident response communication plan. A company officer has suggested that if a data breach occurs, only affected parties should be notified to keep an incident from becoming a media headline. Which of the following should the analyst recommend to the company officer?

choices.D: An attempt to make an SSH connection from an unknown IP address was done using a password.
choices.C: An attempt to make an SSH connection from outside the network was done using PKI.
choices.A: An attempt to make an SSH connection from "superman" was done using a password.
choices.B: An attempt to make an SSH connection from 192.168.1.166 was done using PKI.

discussion.content:
B is correct but worded incorrectly. It should be:
An attempt to make an SSH connection "TO" 192.168.1.166 was done using PKI.

The user is trying to connect via SSH to 192.168.1.166, and not from 192.168.1.166.
The multiple choices are wrong in the first place.

B looks wrong for me. As s3curity1 mentioned, the server is 192.168.1.166, so the connection is "TO", not "FROM".
Wouldn't it be option C? It also states that PKI was used, and says source is outside network.
https://learning.oreilly.com/library/view/regular-expressions-cookbook/9781449327453/ch04s20.html
